oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mapping the Extent of Invasive Phragmites australis subsp. australis From Airborne Hyperspectral Imagery
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Elmer, Kathryn
Kalacska, Margaret
Arroyo-Mora, J. Pablo
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Phragmites australis
invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Invasive species pose one of the greatest threats to global biodiversity. Early detection of invasive species is critical in order to prevent or manage their spread before they exceed the ability of land management groups to control them. Optical remote sensing has been established as a useful technology for the early detection and mapping of invasive vegetation populations. Through the use of airborne hyperspectral imagery (HSI), this study establishes a target detection methodology used to identify and map the invasive reed <jats:italic>Phragmites australis</jats:italic> subsp. <jats:italic>australis</jats:italic> within the entire extent of Îles-de-Boucherville National Park (Quebec, ON, Canada). We applied the Spectral Angle Mapper (SAM) target detection algorithm trained with a high accuracy GNSS ground truth data set to produce a park-wide map illustrating the extent of detected <jats:italic>Phragmites</jats:italic>. The total coverage of detected <jats:italic>Phragmites</jats:italic> was 26.74 ha (0.267 km<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>), which represents 3.28% of the total park area of 814 ha (8.14 km<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>). The inherent spatial uncertainty of the airborne HSI (∼2.25 m) was accounted for with uncertainty buffers, which, when included in the measurement of detected <jats:italic>Phragmites</jats:italic>, lead to a total area of 59.17 ha (0.591 km<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>), or 7.26% of the park. The overall accuracy of the <jats:italic>Phragmites</jats:italic> map was 84.28%, with a sensitivity of 76.32% and a specificity of 91.57%. Additionally, visual interpretation of the validation ground truth dataset was performed by 10 individuals, in order to compare their performance to that of the target detection algorithm. The overall accuracy of the visual interpretation was lower than the target detection (i.e., 69.18%, with a sensitivity of 59.21% and a specificity of 78.31%). Overall, this study is one of the first to utilize airborne HSI and target detection to map the extent of <jats:italic>Phragmites</jats:italic> over a moderately large extent. The uses and limitations of such an approach are established, and the methodology described here in detail could be adapted for future remote sensing studies of <jats:italic>Phragmites</jats:italic> or other vegetation species, native or invasive, at study sites around the world.</jats:p>
